awd_titl_txt: Collaborative: Using Roll Call Votes to Understand Legislative Behavior
awd_abstract_narration:
In most democracies, the public record of legislative votes in national and local parliaments is an important basis for holding elected officials accountable. In political science, that record is also an important source of data on legislator and party behavior. In practice, many legislatures create a public record of the votes cast by individual legislators for only a fraction of the issues on which votes occur. These recorded votes often are not a representative sample of all votes cast and may exhibit systematic biases that have implications for political accountability and for the science of political behavior. Therefore, understanding the characteristics of the issues that receive a publicly recorded vote (a roll-call vote) is essential to our understanding of democratic processes and evaluating the limits of scientific inferences that can be drawn from roll-call data. This study will advance our understanding of the voting record through examination of national parliamentary bodies around the world.

Currently in political science, two accounts, derived from alternative political motivations, serve as the basis of contending explanations of the decision to conduct a recorded vote: disciplining arguments and position-taking arguments. This study (a) develops theory about the implications of these accounts and specifies testable propositions about both what issues come to a vote and what are the consequences for legislators' observable voting patterns; (b) examines the policy domains and legislative sponsors in the full population of votes to the policy domains and legislative sponsors subject to recorded votes; (c) examines the formal rules and political context that condition the issues that receive a recorded or unrecorded vote; and (d) generates and estimates statistical models that account for the effect of expected outcomes on the decision to request a recorded vote. In doing so, the study provides a deeper understanding of the roll-call vote data generating process than political science has had to date, which, in turn, will allow stronger inferences to be drawn from observed voting behavior.

This study is the first systematic effort to understand the roll-call vote data generating process for multiple national parliaments. The study will advance our understanding of democratic presentation, accountability, and responsiveness.  In addition, it will provide a large corpus of data on parliamentary voting that will be important to scholars in the field of comparative legislative politics. Finally, the project will provide graduate students with invaluable research experience.

por.por_cntn:
A well-functioning democracy requires electoral accountability of elected representatives. One of the most important tools of accountability is the voting record of legislators. Those records allow voters to reward or punish their representatives for their policy choices. However, often only a fraction of these votes are available for public scrutiny. In many legislatures around the world, only a minority of legislative decisions provide a record how each individual legislator voted. Importantly, these roll call votes are typically not representative of the full legislative agenda, and they do not necessarily focus on publicly salient bills. Perhaps this is unsurprising given that what is put on public record is often a decision of the legislators themselves. To the degree that legislators, and the parties they constitute, have agendas to manipulate what becomes public record, this fact could be severely undermining electoral accountability. In any event, the properties of that public vote record—what is included and what is left off, why some but not all votes are included, and the resulting level of obfuscation of salient legislative behavior—is critical to whether voters can hold representatives to account and, thus, to democratic performance. Our project seeks to establish these properties of recorded votes across the variety of legislative chambers around the world.

We start by trying to understand the selection of votes for public record. We develop two arguments. One is that it is done so that party leaders can hold their party membership accountable for how they vote (in order to enforce party discipline). The other is that it is done to position-take with the public. Parties want to publicize votes that raise their electoral prospects and that diminish the prospects of their opponents. The arguments have different implications for when we will see roll call votes and the properties of those votes. To investigate the validity of these arguments, we have assembled legislative minutes of a wide variety of countries around the world. Using advanced computer science techniques we are able to use those minutes to statistically test what drives use of roll call votes. From this we can draw conclusions about how effective roll call votes are for monitoring elected officials.

We have two initial findings. First, the two arguments we develop are novel. While they are predicated on conventional wisdom about the motivations for roll call votes, their implications defy that conventional wisdom. For example, if parties are motivated by position-taking, then we should always see roll-call votes under typical conditions. That we do not suggests there is more to the story than simply that motivation. Second, our data collection reveals that for many legislatures the selection issue is substantial; large shares of legislative decisions go unrecorded.
